declarations.comments:
The `Apply` class provides the `(<*>)` which is used to apply a function
to an argument under a type constructor.

`Apply` can be used to lift functions of two or more arguments to work on
values wrapped with the type constructor `f`. It might also be understood
in terms of the `lift2` function:

```purescript
lift2 :: forall f a b c. Apply f => (a -> b -> c) -> f a -> f b -> f c
lift2 f a b = f <$> a <*> b
```

`(<*>)` is recovered from `lift2` as `lift2 ($)`. That is, `(<*>)` lifts
the function application operator `($)` to arguments wrapped with the
type constructor `f`.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Functor`
laws:

- Associative composition: `(<<<) <$> f <*> g <*> h = f <*> (g <*> h)`

Formally, `Apply` represents a strong lax semi-monoidal endofunctor.
declarations.title: Apply

declarations.comments:
A `Functor` is a type constructor which supports a mapping operation
`map`.

`map` can be used to turn functions `a -> b` into functions
`f a -> f b` whose argument and return types use the type constructor `f`
to represent some computational context.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Identity: `map identity = identity`
- Composition: `map (f <<< g) = map f <<< map g`
declarations.title: Functor

declarations.comments:
The `void` function is used to ignore the type wrapped by a
[`Functor`](#functor), replacing it with `Unit` and keeping only the type
information provided by the type constructor itself.

`void` is often useful when using `do` notation to change the return type
of a monadic computation:

```purescript
main = forE 1 10 \n -> void do
  print n
  print (n * n)
```
declarations.title: void

declarations.comments:
The `Applicative` type class extends the [`Apply`](#apply) type class
with a `pure` function, which can be used to create values of type `f a`
from values of type `a`.

Where [`Apply`](#apply) provides the ability to lift functions of two or
more arguments to functions whose arguments are wrapped using `f`, and
[`Functor`](#functor) provides the ability to lift functions of one
argument, `pure` can be seen as the function which lifts functions of
_zero_ arguments. That is, `Applicative` functors support a lifting
operation for any number of function arguments.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the `Apply`
laws:

- Identity: `(pure identity) <*> v = v`
- Composition: `pure (<<<) <*> f <*> g <*> h = f <*> (g <*> h)`
- Homomorphism: `(pure f) <*> (pure x) = pure (f x)`
- Interchange: `u <*> (pure y) = (pure (_ $ y)) <*> u`
declarations.title: Applicative

declarations.comments:
`liftA1` provides a default implementation of `(<$>)` for any
[`Applicative`](#applicative) functor, without using `(<$>)` as provided
by the [`Functor`](#functor)-[`Applicative`](#applicative) superclass
relationship.

`liftA1` can therefore be used to write [`Functor`](#functor) instances
as follows:

```purescript
instance functorF :: Functor F where
  map = liftA1
```
declarations.title: liftA1

declarations.comments: Perform an applicative action unless a condition is true.
declarations.title: unless

declarations.comments: Perform an applicative action when a condition is true.
declarations.title: when

- Identity: `map identity = identity`
- Composition: `map (f <<< g) = map f <<< map g`

declarations.comments:
The `void` function is used to ignore the type wrapped by a
[`Functor`](#functor), replacing it with `Unit` and keeping only the type
information provided by the type constructor itself.

`void` is often useful when using `do` notation to change the return type
of a monadic computation:

```purescript
main = forE 1 10 \n -> void do
  print n
  print (n * n)
```
declarations.title: void

declarations.comments:
The `Bind` type class extends the [`Apply`](#apply) type class with a
"bind" operation `(>>=)` which composes computations in sequence, using
the return value of one computation to determine the next computation.

The `>>=` operator can also be expressed using `do` notation, as follows:

```purescript
x >>= f = do y <- x
             f y
```

where the function argument of `f` is given the name `y`.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Apply`
laws:

- Associativity: `(x >>= f) >>= g = x >>= (\k -> f k >>= g)`

Associativity tells us that we can regroup operations which use `do`
notation so that we can unambiguously write, for example:

```purescript
do x <- m1
   y <- m2 x
   m3 x y
```
declarations.title: Bind

declarations.comments:
`bindFlipped` is `bind` with its arguments reversed. For example:

```purescript
print =<< random
```
declarations.title: bindFlipped

declarations.comments:
A class for types whose values can safely be discarded
in a `do` notation block.

An example is the `Unit` type, since there is only one
possible value which can be returned.
declarations.title: Discard

declarations.comments: Collapse two applications of a monadic type constructor into one.
declarations.title: join

declarations.comments:
Forwards Kleisli composition.

For example:

```purescript
import Data.Array (head, tail)

third = tail >=> tail >=> head
```
declarations.title: composeKleisli

declarations.comments: Backwards Kleisli composition.
declarations.title: composeKleisliFlipped

declarations.comments:
Execute a monadic action if a condition holds.

For example:

```purescript
main = ifM ((< 0.5) <$> random)
         (trace "Heads")
         (trace "Tails")
```
declarations.title: ifM

declarations.comments:
A `Semigroupoid` is similar to a [`Category`](#category) but does not
require an identity element `identity`, just composable morphisms.

`Semigroupoid`s must satisfy the following law:

- Associativity: `p <<< (q <<< r) = (p <<< q) <<< r`

One example of a `Semigroupoid` is the function type constructor `(->)`,
with `(<<<)` defined as function composition.
declarations.title: Semigroupoid

declarations.comments:
`Category`s consist of objects and composable morphisms between them, and
as such are [`Semigroupoids`](#semigroupoid), but unlike `semigroupoids`
must have an identity element.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the
`Semigroupoid` law:

- Identity: `identity <<< p = p <<< identity = p`
declarations.title: Category

declarations.comments:

Where [`Apply`](#apply) provides the ability to lift functions of two or

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the `Apply`
laws:

- Identity: `(pure identity) <*> v = v`
- Composition: `pure (<<<) <*> f <*> g <*> h = f <*> (g <*> h)`
- Homomorphism: `(pure f) <*> (pure x) = pure (f x)`
- Interchange: `u <*> (pure y) = (pure (_ $ y)) <*> u`
declarations.title: Applicative

A `Functor` is a type constructor which supports a mapping operation
`map`.

`map` can be used to turn functions `a -> b` into functions
`f a -> f b` whose argument and return types use the type constructor `f`
to represent some computational context.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

declarations.comments:
The `void` function is used to ignore the type wrapped by a

declarations.comments:
The `Monad` type class combines the operations of the `Bind` and
`Applicative` type classes. Therefore, `Monad` instances represent type
constructors which support sequential composition, and also lifting of
functions of arbitrary arity.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the
`Applicative` and `Bind` laws:

- Left Identity: `pure x >>= f = f x`
- Right Identity: `x >>= pure = x`
- Applicative Superclass: `apply = ap`
declarations.title: Monad

declarations.comments:
`liftM1` provides a default implementation of `(<$>)` for any
[`Monad`](#monad), without using `(<$>)` as provided by the
[`Functor`](#functor)-[`Monad`](#monad) superclass relationship.

`liftM1` can therefore be used to write [`Functor`](#functor) instances
as follows:

```purescript
instance functorF :: Functor F where
  map = liftM1
```
declarations.title: liftM1

declarations.comments:
`ap` provides a default implementation of `(<*>)` for any
[`Monad`](#monad), without using `(<*>)` as provided by the
[`Apply`](#apply)-[`Monad`](#monad) superclass relationship.

`ap` can therefore be used to write [`Apply`](#apply) instances as
follows:

```purescript
instance applyF :: Apply F where
  apply = ap
```
declarations.title: ap

declarations.comments:
Perform a monadic action when a condition is true, where the conditional
value is also in a monadic context.
declarations.title: whenM

declarations.comments:
Perform a monadic action unless a condition is true, where the conditional
value is also in a monadic context.
declarations.title: unlessM

declarations.comments:
A `Semigroupoid` is similar to a [`Category`](#category) but does not
require an identity element `identity`, just composable morphisms.

`Semigroupoid`s must satisfy the following law:

- Associativity: `p <<< (q <<< r) = (p <<< q) <<< r`

One example of a `Semigroupoid` is the function type constructor `(->)`,
with `(<<<)` defined as function composition.
declarations.title: Semigroupoid

declarations.comments: Forwards composition, or `compose` with its arguments reversed.
declarations.title: composeFlipped

declarations.comments:
An alias for `true`, which can be useful in guard clauses:

```purescript
max x y | x >= y    = x
        | otherwise = y
```
declarations.title: otherwise

declarations.comments:
The `HeytingAlgebra` type class represents types that are bounded lattices with
an implication operator such that the following laws hold:

- Associativity:
  - `a || (b || c) = (a || b) || c`
  - `a && (b && c) = (a && b) && c`
- Commutativity:
  - `a || b = b || a`
  - `a && b = b && a`
- Absorption:
  - `a || (a && b) = a`
  - `a && (a || b) = a`
- Idempotent:
  - `a || a = a`
  - `a && a = a`
- Identity:
  - `a || ff = a`
  - `a && tt = a`
- Implication:
  - ``a `implies` a = tt``
  - ``a && (a `implies` b) = a && b``
  - ``b && (a `implies` b) = b``
  - ``a `implies` (b && c) = (a `implies` b) && (a `implies` c)``
- Complemented:
  - ``not a = a `implies` ff``
declarations.title: HeytingAlgebra

declarations.comments:
A class for records where all fields have `HeytingAlgebra` instances, used
to implement the `HeytingAlgebra` instance for records.
declarations.title: HeytingAlgebraRecord

declarations.comments:
The `BooleanAlgebra` type class represents types that behave like boolean
values.

Instances should satisfy the following laws in addition to the
`HeytingAlgebra` law:

- Excluded middle:
  - `a || not a = tt`
declarations.title: BooleanAlgebra

declarations.comments:
A class for records where all fields have `BooleanAlgebra` instances, used
to implement the `BooleanAlgebra` instance for records.
declarations.title: BooleanAlgebraRecord

declarations.comments:
The `Ordering` data type represents the three possible outcomes of
comparing two values:

`LT` - The first value is _less than_ the second.
`GT` - The first value is _greater than_ the second.
`EQ` - The first value is _equal to_ the second.
declarations.title: Ordering

declarations.comments:
The `Ord` type class represents types which support comparisons with a
_total order_.

`Ord` instances should satisfy the laws of total orderings:

- Reflexivity: `a <= a`
- Antisymmetry: if `a <= b` and `b <= a` then `a = b`
- Transitivity: if `a <= b` and `b <= c` then `a <= c`
declarations.title: Ord

children.comments:
The `Bounded` `Int` instance has `top :: Int` equal to 2^31 - 1,
and `bottom :: Int` equal to -2^31, since these are the largest and smallest
integers representable by twos-complement 32-bit integers, respectively.
children.title: boundedInt

children.comments: Characters fall within the Unicode range.
children.title: boundedChar

declarations.comments:
The `Bounded` type class represents totally ordered types that have an
upper and lower boundary.

Instances should satisfy the following law in addition to the `Ord` laws:

- Bounded: `bottom <= a <= top`
declarations.title: Bounded

declarations.comments:
The `Ring` class is for types that support addition, multiplication,
and subtraction operations.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Semiring`
laws:

- Additive inverse: `a - a = (zero - a) + a = zero`
declarations.title: Ring

declarations.comments:
A class for records where all fields have `Ring` instances, used to
implement the `Ring` instance for records.
declarations.title: RingRecord

declarations.comments:
The `Semiring` class is for types that support an addition and
multiplication operation.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Commutative monoid under addition:
  - Associativity: `(a + b) + c = a + (b + c)`
  - Identity: `zero + a = a + zero = a`
  - Commutative: `a + b = b + a`
- Monoid under multiplication:
  - Associativity: `(a * b) * c = a * (b * c)`
  - Identity: `one * a = a * one = a`
- Multiplication distributes over addition:
  - Left distributivity: `a * (b + c) = (a * b) + (a * c)`
  - Right distributivity: `(a + b) * c = (a * c) + (b * c)`
- Annihilation: `zero * a = a * zero = zero`

**Note:** The `Number` and `Int` types are not fully law abiding
members of this class hierarchy due to the potential for arithmetic
overflows, and in the case of `Number`, the presence of `NaN` and
`Infinity` values. The behaviour is unspecified in these cases.
declarations.title: Semiring

declarations.comments:
The `CommutativeRing` class is for rings where multiplication is
commutative.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Ring`
laws:

- Commutative multiplication: `a * b = b * a`
declarations.title: CommutativeRing

declarations.comments:
A class for records where all fields have `CommutativeRing` instances, used
to implement the `CommutativeRing` instance for records.
declarations.title: CommutativeRingRecord

declarations.comments:
The `Ring` class is for types that support addition, multiplication,
and subtraction operations.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Semiring`
laws:

- Additive inverse: `a - a = (zero - a) + a = zero`
declarations.title: Ring

declarations.comments: `negate x` can be used as a shorthand for `zero - x`.
declarations.title: negate

declarations.comments:
The `Semiring` class is for types that support an addition and
multiplication operation.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Commutative monoid under addition:
  - Associativity: `(a + b) + c = a + (b + c)`
  - Identity: `zero + a = a + zero = a`
  - Commutative: `a + b = b + a`
- Monoid under multiplication:
  - Associativity: `(a * b) * c = a * (b * c)`
  - Identity: `one * a = a * one = a`
- Multiplication distributes over addition:
  - Left distributivity: `a * (b + c) = (a * b) + (a * c)`
  - Right distributivity: `(a + b) * c = (a * c) + (b * c)`
- Annihilation: `zero * a = a * zero = zero`

**Note:** The `Number` and `Int` types are not fully law abiding
members of this class hierarchy due to the potential for arithmetic
overflows, and in the case of `Number`, the presence of `NaN` and
`Infinity` values. The behaviour is unspecified in these cases.
declarations.title: Semiring

declarations.comments:
The `DivisionRing` class is for non-zero rings in which every non-zero
element has a multiplicative inverse. Division rings are sometimes also
called *skew fields*.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the `Ring` laws:

- Non-zero ring: `one /= zero`
- Non-zero multiplicative inverse: `recip a * a = a * recip a = one` for
  all non-zero `a`

The result of `recip zero` is left undefined; individual instances may
choose how to handle this case.

If a type has both `DivisionRing` and `CommutativeRing` instances, then
it is a field and should have a `Field` instance.
declarations.title: DivisionRing

declarations.comments:
Left division, defined as `leftDiv a b = recip b * a`. Left and right
division are distinct in this module because a `DivisionRing` is not
necessarily commutative.

If the type `a` is also a `EuclideanRing`, then this function is
equivalent to `div` from the `EuclideanRing` class. When working
abstractly, `div` should generally be preferred, unless you know that you
need your code to work with noncommutative rings.
declarations.title: leftDiv

declarations.comments:
Right division, defined as `rightDiv a b = a * recip b`. Left and right
division are distinct in this module because a `DivisionRing` is not
necessarily commutative.

If the type `a` is also a `EuclideanRing`, then this function is
equivalent to `div` from the `EuclideanRing` class. When working
abstractly, `div` should generally be preferred, unless you know that you
need your code to work with noncommutative rings.
declarations.title: rightDiv

declarations.comments:
The `Eq` type class represents types which support decidable equality.

`Eq` instances should satisfy the following laws:

- Reflexivity: `x == x = true`
- Symmetry: `x == y = y == x`
- Transitivity: if `x == y` and `y == z` then `x == z`

**Note:** The `Number` type is not an entirely law abiding member of this
class due to the presence of `NaN`, since `NaN /= NaN`. Additionally,
computing with `Number` can result in a loss of precision, so sometimes
values that should be equivalent are not.
declarations.title: Eq

declarations.comments:
`notEq` tests whether one value is _not equal_ to another. Shorthand for
`not (eq x y)`.
declarations.title: notEq

declarations.comments: The `Eq1` type class represents type constructors with decidable equality.
declarations.title: Eq1

declarations.comments:
A class for records where all fields have `Eq` instances, used to implement
the `Eq` instance for records.
declarations.title: EqRecord

declarations.comments:
The `CommutativeRing` class is for rings where multiplication is
commutative.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Ring`
laws:

- Commutative multiplication: `a * b = b * a`
declarations.title: CommutativeRing

declarations.comments:
The `Ring` class is for types that support addition, multiplication,
and subtraction operations.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Semiring`
laws:

- Additive inverse: `a - a = (zero - a) + a = zero`
declarations.title: Ring

declarations.comments:
The `Semiring` class is for types that support an addition and
multiplication operation.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Commutative monoid under addition:
  - Associativity: `(a + b) + c = a + (b + c)`
  - Identity: `zero + a = a + zero = a`
  - Commutative: `a + b = b + a`
- Monoid under multiplication:
  - Associativity: `(a * b) * c = a * (b * c)`
  - Identity: `one * a = a * one = a`
- Multiplication distributes over addition:
  - Left distributivity: `a * (b + c) = (a * b) + (a * c)`
  - Right distributivity: `(a + b) * c = (a * c) + (b * c)`
- Annihilation: `zero * a = a * zero = zero`

**Note:** The `Number` and `Int` types are not fully law abiding
members of this class hierarchy due to the potential for arithmetic
overflows, and in the case of `Number`, the presence of `NaN` and
`Infinity` values. The behaviour is unspecified in these cases.
declarations.title: Semiring

declarations.comments:
The `EuclideanRing` class is for commutative rings that support division.
The mathematical structure this class is based on is sometimes also called
a *Euclidean domain*.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the `Ring`
laws:

- Integral domain: `one /= zero`, and if `a` and `b` are both nonzero then
  so is their product `a * b`
- Euclidean function `degree`:
  - Nonnegativity: For all nonzero `a`, `degree a >= 0`
  - Quotient/remainder: For all `a` and `b`, where `b` is nonzero,
    let `q = a / b` and ``r = a `mod` b``; then `a = q*b + r`, and also
    either `r = zero` or `degree r < degree b`
- Submultiplicative euclidean function:
  - For all nonzero `a` and `b`, `degree a <= degree (a * b)`

The behaviour of division by `zero` is unconstrained by these laws,
meaning that individual instances are free to choose how to behave in this
case. Similarly, there are no restrictions on what the result of
`degree zero` is; it doesn't make sense to ask for `degree zero` in the
same way that it doesn't make sense to divide by `zero`, so again,
individual instances may choose how to handle this case.

For any `EuclideanRing` which is also a `Field`, one valid choice
for `degree` is simply `const 1`. In fact, unless there's a specific
reason not to, `Field` types should normally use this definition of
`degree`.

The `EuclideanRing Int` instance is one of the most commonly used
`EuclideanRing` instances and deserves a little more discussion. In
particular, there are a few different sensible law-abiding implementations
to choose from, with slightly different behaviour in the presence of
negative dividends or divisors. The most common definitions are "truncating"
division, where the result of `a / b` is rounded towards 0, and "Knuthian"
or "flooring" division, where the result of `a / b` is rounded towards
negative infinity. A slightly less common, but arguably more useful, option
is "Euclidean" division, which is defined so as to ensure that ``a `mod` b``
is always nonnegative. With Euclidean division, `a / b` rounds towards
negative infinity if the divisor is positive, and towards positive infinity
if the divisor is negative. Note that all three definitions are identical if
we restrict our attention to nonnegative dividends and divisors.

In versions 1.x, 2.x, and 3.x of the Prelude, the `EuclideanRing Int`
instance used truncating division. As of 4.x, the `EuclideanRing Int`
instance uses Euclidean division. Additional functions `quot` and `rem` are
supplied if truncating division is desired.
declarations.title: EuclideanRing

declarations.comments: The *greatest common divisor* of two values.
declarations.title: gcd

declarations.comments: The *least common multiple* of two values.
declarations.title: lcm

declarations.comments:
The `CommutativeRing` class is for rings where multiplication is
commutative.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Ring`
laws:

- Commutative multiplication: `a * b = b * a`
declarations.title: CommutativeRing

declarations.comments:
The `DivisionRing` class is for non-zero rings in which every non-zero
element has a multiplicative inverse. Division rings are sometimes also
called *skew fields*.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the `Ring` laws:

- Non-zero ring: `one /= zero`
- Non-zero multiplicative inverse: `recip a * a = a * recip a = one` for
  all non-zero `a`

The result of `recip zero` is left undefined; individual instances may
choose how to handle this case.

If a type has both `DivisionRing` and `CommutativeRing` instances, then
it is a field and should have a `Field` instance.
declarations.title: DivisionRing

declarations.comments:
The `EuclideanRing` class is for commutative rings that support division.
The mathematical structure this class is based on is sometimes also called
a *Euclidean domain*.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the `Ring`
laws:

- Integral domain: `one /= zero`, and if `a` and `b` are both nonzero then
  so is their product `a * b`
- Euclidean function `degree`:
  - Nonnegativity: For all nonzero `a`, `degree a >= 0`
  - Quotient/remainder: For all `a` and `b`, where `b` is nonzero,
    let `q = a / b` and ``r = a `mod` b``; then `a = q*b + r`, and also
    either `r = zero` or `degree r < degree b`
- Submultiplicative euclidean function:
  - For all nonzero `a` and `b`, `degree a <= degree (a * b)`

The behaviour of division by `zero` is unconstrained by these laws,
meaning that individual instances are free to choose how to behave in this
case. Similarly, there are no restrictions on what the result of
`degree zero` is; it doesn't make sense to ask for `degree zero` in the
same way that it doesn't make sense to divide by `zero`, so again,
individual instances may choose how to handle this case.

For any `EuclideanRing` which is also a `Field`, one valid choice
for `degree` is simply `const 1`. In fact, unless there's a specific
reason not to, `Field` types should normally use this definition of
`degree`.

The `EuclideanRing Int` instance is one of the most commonly used
`EuclideanRing` instances and deserves a little more discussion. In
particular, there are a few different sensible law-abiding implementations
to choose from, with slightly different behaviour in the presence of
negative dividends or divisors. The most common definitions are "truncating"
division, where the result of `a / b` is rounded towards 0, and "Knuthian"
or "flooring" division, where the result of `a / b` is rounded towards
negative infinity. A slightly less common, but arguably more useful, option
is "Euclidean" division, which is defined so as to ensure that ``a `mod` b``
is always nonnegative. With Euclidean division, `a / b` rounds towards
negative infinity if the divisor is positive, and towards positive infinity
if the divisor is negative. Note that all three definitions are identical if
we restrict our attention to nonnegative dividends and divisors.

In versions 1.x, 2.x, and 3.x of the Prelude, the `EuclideanRing Int`
instance used truncating division. As of 4.x, the `EuclideanRing Int`
instance uses Euclidean division. Additional functions `quot` and `rem` are
supplied if truncating division is desired.
declarations.title: EuclideanRing

declarations.comments: The *least common multiple* of two values.
declarations.title: lcm

declarations.comments: The *greatest common divisor* of two values.
declarations.title: gcd

declarations.comments:
The `Ring` class is for types that support addition, multiplication,
and subtraction operations.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Semiring`
laws:

- Additive inverse: `a - a = (zero - a) + a = zero`
declarations.title: Ring

declarations.comments: `negate x` can be used as a shorthand for `zero - x`.
declarations.title: negate

declarations.comments:
The `Semiring` class is for types that support an addition and
multiplication operation.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Commutative monoid under addition:
  - Associativity: `(a + b) + c = a + (b + c)`
  - Identity: `zero + a = a + zero = a`
  - Commutative: `a + b = b + a`
- Monoid under multiplication:
  - Associativity: `(a * b) * c = a * (b * c)`
  - Identity: `one * a = a * one = a`
- Multiplication distributes over addition:
  - Left distributivity: `a * (b + c) = (a * b) + (a * c)`
  - Right distributivity: `(a + b) * c = (a * c) + (b * c)`
- Annihilation: `zero * a = a * zero = zero`

**Note:** The `Number` and `Int` types are not fully law abiding
members of this class hierarchy due to the potential for arithmetic
overflows, and in the case of `Number`, the presence of `NaN` and
`Infinity` values. The behaviour is unspecified in these cases.
declarations.title: Semiring

declarations.comments:
The `Field` class is for types that are (commutative) fields.

Mathematically, a field is a ring which is commutative and in which every
nonzero element has a multiplicative inverse; these conditions correspond
to the `CommutativeRing` and `DivisionRing` classes in PureScript
respectively. However, the `Field` class has `EuclideanRing` and
`DivisionRing` as superclasses, which seems like a stronger requirement
(since `CommutativeRing` is a superclass of `EuclideanRing`). In fact, it
is not stronger, since any type which has law-abiding `CommutativeRing`
and `DivisionRing` instances permits exactly one law-abiding
`EuclideanRing` instance. We use a `EuclideanRing` superclass here in
order to ensure that a `Field` constraint on a function permits you to use
`div` on that type, since `div` is a member of `EuclideanRing`.

This class has no laws or members of its own; it exists as a convenience,
so a single constraint can be used when field-like behaviour is expected.

This module also defines a single `Field` instance for any type which has
both `EuclideanRing` and `DivisionRing` instances. Any other instance
would overlap with this instance, so no other `Field` instances should be
defined in libraries. Instead, simply define `EuclideanRing` and
`DivisionRing` instances, and this will permit your type to be used with a
`Field` constraint.
declarations.title: Field

declarations.comments:
Flips the order of the arguments to a function of two arguments.

```purescript
flip const 1 2 = const 2 1 = 2
```
declarations.title: flip

declarations.comments:
Returns its first argument and ignores its second.

```purescript
const 1 "hello" = 1
```
declarations.title: const

declarations.comments:
Applies a function to an argument. This is primarily used as the operator
`($)` which allows parentheses to be omitted in some cases, or as a
natural way to apply a chain of composed functions to a value.
declarations.title: apply

declarations.comments:
Applies a function to an argument: the reverse of `(#)`.

```purescript
length $ groupBy productCategory $ filter isInStock $ products
```

is equivalent to:

```purescript
length (groupBy productCategory (filter isInStock products))
```

Or another alternative equivalent, applying chain of composed functions to
a value:

```purescript
length <<< groupBy productCategory <<< filter isInStock $ products
```

Applies an argument to a function. This is primarily used as the `(#)`
operator, which allows parentheses to be ommitted in some cases, or as a
natural way to apply a value to a chain of composed functions.
declarations.title: applyFlipped

declarations.comments:
Applies an argument to a function: the reverse of `($)`.

```purescript
products # filter isInStock # groupBy productCategory # length
```

is equivalent to:

```purescript
length (groupBy productCategory (filter isInStock products))
```

Or another alternative equivalent, applying a value to a chain of composed
functions:

```purescript
products # filter isInStock >>> groupBy productCategory >>> length
```

`applyN f n` applies the function `f` to its argument `n` times.

If n is less than or equal to 0, the function is not applied.

```purescript
applyN (_ + 1) 10 0 == 10
```
declarations.title: applyN

declarations.comments:
The `on` function is used to change the domain of a binary operator.

For example, we can create a function which compares two records based on the values of their `x` properties:

```purescript
compareX :: forall r. { x :: Number | r } -> { x :: Number | r } -> Ordering
compareX = compare `on` _.x
```
declarations.title: on

declarations.comments:
A `Functor` is a type constructor which supports a mapping operation
`map`.

`map` can be used to turn functions `a -> b` into functions
`f a -> f b` whose argument and return types use the type constructor `f`
to represent some computational context.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Identity: `map identity = identity`
- Composition: `map (f <<< g) = map f <<< map g`
declarations.title: Functor

declarations.comments:
`mapFlipped` is `map` with its arguments reversed. For example:

```purescript
[1, 2, 3] <#> \n -> n * n
```
declarations.title: mapFlipped

declarations.comments:
The `void` function is used to ignore the type wrapped by a
[`Functor`](#functor), replacing it with `Unit` and keeping only the type
information provided by the type constructor itself.

`void` is often useful when using `do` notation to change the return type
of a monadic computation:

```purescript
main = forE 1 10 \n -> void do
  print n
  print (n * n)
```
declarations.title: void

declarations.comments:
Ignore the return value of a computation, using the specified return value
instead.
declarations.title: voidRight

declarations.comments: A version of `voidRight` with its arguments flipped.
declarations.title: voidLeft

declarations.comments:
Apply a value in a computational context to a value in no context.

Generalizes `flip`.

```purescript
longEnough :: String -> Bool
hasSymbol :: String -> Bool
hasDigit :: String -> Bool
password :: String

validate :: String -> Array Bool
validate = flap [longEnough, hasSymbol, hasDigit]
```

```purescript
flap (-) 3 4 == 1
threeve <$> Just 1 <@> 'a' <*> Just true == Just (threeve 1 'a' true)
```
declarations.title: flap

declarations.comments:
The `HeytingAlgebra` type class represents types that are bounded lattices with
an implication operator such that the following laws hold:

- Associativity:
  - `a || (b || c) = (a || b) || c`
  - `a && (b && c) = (a && b) && c`
- Commutativity:
  - `a || b = b || a`
  - `a && b = b && a`
- Absorption:
  - `a || (a && b) = a`
  - `a && (a || b) = a`
- Idempotent:
  - `a || a = a`
  - `a && a = a`
- Identity:
  - `a || ff = a`
  - `a && tt = a`
- Implication:
  - ``a `implies` a = tt``
  - ``a && (a `implies` b) = a && b``
  - ``b && (a `implies` b) = b``
  - ``a `implies` (b && c) = (a `implies` b) && (a `implies` c)``
- Complemented:
  - ``not a = a `implies` ff``
declarations.title: HeytingAlgebra

declarations.comments:
A class for records where all fields have `HeytingAlgebra` instances, used
to implement the `HeytingAlgebra` instance for records.
declarations.title: HeytingAlgebraRecord

declarations.comments:
The `Semigroup` type class identifies an associative operation on a type.

Instances are required to satisfy the following law:

- Associativity: `(x <> y) <> z = x <> (y <> z)`

One example of a `Semigroup` is `String`, with `(<>)` defined as string
concatenation.
declarations.title: Semigroup

declarations.comments:
A class for records where all fields have `Semigroup` instances, used to
implement the `Semigroup` instance for records.
declarations.title: SemigroupRecord

declarations.comments:
A `Monoid` is a `Semigroup` with a value `mempty`, which is both a
left and right unit for the associative operation `<>`:

```
forall x. mempty <> x = x <> mempty = x
```

`Monoid`s are commonly used as the result of fold operations, where
`<>` is used to combine individual results, and `mempty` gives the result
of folding an empty collection of elements.
declarations.title: Monoid

declarations.comments:
Append a value to itself a certain number of times. For the
`Multiplicative` type, and for a non-negative power, this is the same as
normal number exponentiation.

If the second argument is negative this function will return `mempty`
(*unlike* normal number exponentiation). The `Monoid` constraint alone
is not enough to write a `power` function with the property that `power x
n` cancels with `power x (-n)`, i.e. `power x n <> power x (-n) = mempty`.
For that, we would additionally need the ability to invert elements, i.e.
a Group.
declarations.title: power

declarations.comments: Allow or "truncate" a Monoid to its `mempty` value based on a condition.
declarations.title: guard

declarations.comments:
A class for records where all fields have `Monoid` instances, used to
implement the `Monoid` instance for records.
declarations.title: MonoidRecord

declarations.comments:
Monoid and semigroup for semirings under addition.

``` purescript
Additive x <> Additive y == Additive (x + y)
mempty :: Additive _ == Additive zero
```
declarations.title: Additive

declarations.comments:
Monoid and semigroup for conjuntion.

``` purescript
Conj x <> Conj y == Conj (x && y)
mempty :: Conj _ == Conj top
```
declarations.title: Conj

declarations.comments:
Monoid and semigroup for disjunction.

``` purescript
Disj x <> Disj y == Disj (x || y)
mempty :: Disj _ == Disj bottom
```
declarations.title: Disj

declarations.comments:
The dual of a monoid.

``` purescript
Dual x <> Dual y == Dual (y <> x)
mempty :: Dual _ == Dual mempty
```
declarations.title: Dual

declarations.comments:
Monoid and semigroup for category endomorphisms.

When `c` is instantiated with `->` this composes functions of type
`a -> a`:

``` purescript
Endo f <> Endo g == Endo (f <<< g)
mempty :: Endo _ == Endo identity
```
declarations.title: Endo

declarations.comments:
Monoid and semigroup for semirings under multiplication.

``` purescript
Multiplicative x <> Multiplicative y == Multiplicative (x * y)
mempty :: Multiplicative _ == Multiplicative one
```
declarations.title: Multiplicative

declarations.comments:
A type for natural transformations.

A natural transformation is a mapping between type constructors of kind
`* -> *` where the mapping operation has no ability to manipulate the
inner values.

An example of this is the `fromFoldable` function provided in
`purescript-lists`, where some foldable structure containing values of
type `a` is converted into a `List a`.

The definition of a natural transformation in category theory states that
`f` and `g` should be functors, but the `Functor` constraint is not
enforced here; that the types are of kind `* -> *` is enough for our
purposes.
declarations.title: NaturalTransformation

declarations.comments:
The `Ordering` data type represents the three possible outcomes of
comparing two values:

`LT` - The first value is _less than_ the second.
`GT` - The first value is _greater than_ the second.
`EQ` - The first value is _equal to_ the second.
declarations.title: Ordering

declarations.comments:
The `Ord` type class represents types which support comparisons with a
_total order_.

`Ord` instances should satisfy the laws of total orderings:

- Reflexivity: `a <= a`
- Antisymmetry: if `a <= b` and `b <= a` then `a = b`
- Transitivity: if `a <= b` and `b <= c` then `a <= c`
declarations.title: Ord

declarations.comments: The `Ord1` type class represents totally ordered type constructors.
declarations.title: Ord1

declarations.comments: Test whether one value is _strictly less than_ another.
declarations.title: lessThan

declarations.comments: Test whether one value is _non-strictly less than_ another.
declarations.title: lessThanOrEq

declarations.comments: Test whether one value is _strictly greater than_ another.
declarations.title: greaterThan

declarations.comments: Test whether one value is _non-strictly greater than_ another.
declarations.title: greaterThanOrEq

declarations.comments: Compares two values by mapping them to a type with an `Ord` instance.
declarations.title: comparing

declarations.comments:
Take the minimum of two values. If they are considered equal, the first
argument is chosen.
declarations.title: min

declarations.comments:
Take the maximum of two values. If they are considered equal, the first
argument is chosen.
declarations.title: max

declarations.comments:
Clamp a value between a minimum and a maximum. For example:

``` purescript
let f = clamp 0 10
f (-5) == 0
f 5    == 5
f 15   == 10
```
declarations.title: clamp

declarations.comments:
Test whether a value is between a minimum and a maximum (inclusive).
For example:

``` purescript
let f = between 0 10
f 0    == true
f (-5) == false
f 5    == true
f 10   == true
f 15   == false
```
declarations.title: between

declarations.comments:
The absolute value function. `abs x` is defined as `if x >= zero then x
else negate x`.
declarations.title: abs

declarations.comments:
The sign function; always evaluates to either `one` or `negate one`. For
any `x`, we should have `signum x * abs x == x`.
declarations.title: signum

declarations.comments:
The `Ordering` data type represents the three possible outcomes of
comparing two values:

`LT` - The first value is _less than_ the second.
`GT` - The first value is _greater than_ the second.
`EQ` - The first value is _equal to_ the second.
declarations.title: Ordering

declarations.comments:
Reverses an `Ordering` value, flipping greater than for less than while
preserving equality.
declarations.title: invert

declarations.comments:
The `Semiring` class is for types that support an addition and
multiplication operation.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Commutative monoid under addition:
  - Associativity: `(a + b) + c = a + (b + c)`
  - Identity: `zero + a = a + zero = a`
  - Commutative: `a + b = b + a`
- Monoid under multiplication:
  - Associativity: `(a * b) * c = a * (b * c)`
  - Identity: `one * a = a * one = a`
- Multiplication distributes over addition:
  - Left distributivity: `a * (b + c) = (a * b) + (a * c)`
  - Right distributivity: `(a + b) * c = (a * c) + (b * c)`
- Annihilation: `zero * a = a * zero = zero`

**Note:** The `Number` and `Int` types are not fully law abiding
members of this class hierarchy due to the potential for arithmetic
overflows, and in the case of `Number`, the presence of `NaN` and
`Infinity` values. The behaviour is unspecified in these cases.
declarations.title: Semiring

declarations.comments:
A class for records where all fields have `Semiring` instances, used to
implement the `Semiring` instance for records.
declarations.title: SemiringRecord

declarations.comments:
The `Ring` class is for types that support addition, multiplication,
and subtraction operations.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Semiring`
laws:

- Additive inverse: `a - a = (zero - a) + a = zero`
declarations.title: Ring

declarations.comments: `negate x` can be used as a shorthand for `zero - x`.
declarations.title: negate

declarations.comments:
A class for records where all fields have `Ring` instances, used to
implement the `Ring` instance for records.
declarations.title: RingRecord

declarations.comments:
The `Semigroup` type class identifies an associative operation on a type.

Instances are required to satisfy the following law:

- Associativity: `(x <> y) <> z = x <> (y <> z)`

One example of a `Semigroup` is `String`, with `(<>)` defined as string
concatenation.
declarations.title: Semigroup

declarations.comments:
A class for records where all fields have `Semigroup` instances, used to
implement the `Semigroup` instance for records.
declarations.title: SemigroupRecord

declarations.comments:
Semigroup where `append` always takes the first option.

``` purescript
First x <> First y == First x
```
declarations.title: First

declarations.comments:
Semigroup where `append` always takes the second option.

``` purescript
Last x <> Last y == Last x
```
declarations.title: Last

declarations.comments:
The `Semiring` class is for types that support an addition and
multiplication operation.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Commutative monoid under addition:
  - Associativity: `(a + b) + c = a + (b + c)`
  - Identity: `zero + a = a + zero = a`
  - Commutative: `a + b = b + a`
- Monoid under multiplication:
  - Associativity: `(a * b) * c = a * (b * c)`
  - Identity: `one * a = a * one = a`
- Multiplication distributes over addition:
  - Left distributivity: `a * (b + c) = (a * b) + (a * c)`
  - Right distributivity: `(a + b) * c = (a * c) + (b * c)`
- Annihilation: `zero * a = a * zero = zero`

**Note:** The `Number` and `Int` types are not fully law abiding
members of this class hierarchy due to the potential for arithmetic
overflows, and in the case of `Number`, the presence of `NaN` and
`Infinity` values. The behaviour is unspecified in these cases.
declarations.title: Semiring

declarations.comments:
A class for records where all fields have `Semiring` instances, used to
implement the `Semiring` instance for records.
declarations.title: SemiringRecord

declarations.comments:
The `Show` type class represents those types which can be converted into
a human-readable `String` representation.

While not required, it is recommended that for any expression `x`, the
string `show x` be executable PureScript code which evaluates to the same
value as the expression `x`.
declarations.title: Show

declarations.comments:
A class for records where all fields have `Show` instances, used to
implement the `Show` instance for records.
declarations.title: ShowRecordFields

declarations.comments: A class for known symbols
declarations.title: IsSymbol

declarations.comments: A value-level proxy for a type-level symbol.
declarations.title: SProxy

declarations.comments:
The `Unit` type has a single inhabitant, called `unit`. It represents
values with no computational content.

`Unit` is often used, wrapped in a monadic type constructor, as the
return type of a computation where only
the _effects_ are important.
declarations.title: Unit

declarations.comments: `unit` is the sole inhabitant of the `Unit` type.
declarations.title: unit

declarations.comments:
An uninhabited data type.

`Void` is useful to eliminate the possibility of a value being created.
For example, a value of type `Either Void Boolean` can never have
a Left value created in PureScript.
declarations.title: Void

declarations.comments:
The `Applicative` type class extends the [`Apply`](#apply) type class
with a `pure` function, which can be used to create values of type `f a`
from values of type `a`.

Where [`Apply`](#apply) provides the ability to lift functions of two or
more arguments to functions whose arguments are wrapped using `f`, and
[`Functor`](#functor) provides the ability to lift functions of one
argument, `pure` can be seen as the function which lifts functions of
_zero_ arguments. That is, `Applicative` functors support a lifting
operation for any number of function arguments.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the `Apply`
laws:

- Identity: `(pure identity) <*> v = v`
- Composition: `pure (<<<) <*> f <*> g <*> h = f <*> (g <*> h)`
- Homomorphism: `(pure f) <*> (pure x) = pure (f x)`
- Interchange: `u <*> (pure y) = (pure (_ $ y)) <*> u`
declarations.title: Applicative

declarations.comments: Perform an applicative action when a condition is true.
declarations.title: when

declarations.comments: Perform an applicative action unless a condition is true.
declarations.title: unless

declarations.comments:
`liftA1` provides a default implementation of `(<$>)` for any
[`Applicative`](#applicative) functor, without using `(<$>)` as provided
by the [`Functor`](#functor)-[`Applicative`](#applicative) superclass
relationship.

`liftA1` can therefore be used to write [`Functor`](#functor) instances
as follows:

```purescript
instance functorF :: Functor F where
  map = liftA1
```
declarations.title: liftA1

declarations.comments:
The `Apply` class provides the `(<*>)` which is used to apply a function
to an argument under a type constructor.

`Apply` can be used to lift functions of two or more arguments to work on
values wrapped with the type constructor `f`. It might also be understood
in terms of the `lift2` function:

```purescript
lift2 :: forall f a b c. Apply f => (a -> b -> c) -> f a -> f b -> f c
lift2 f a b = f <$> a <*> b
```

`(<*>)` is recovered from `lift2` as `lift2 ($)`. That is, `(<*>)` lifts
the function application operator `($)` to arguments wrapped with the
type constructor `f`.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Functor`
laws:

- Associative composition: `(<<<) <$> f <*> g <*> h = f <*> (g <*> h)`

Formally, `Apply` represents a strong lax semi-monoidal endofunctor.
declarations.title: Apply

declarations.comments:
The `Bind` type class extends the [`Apply`](#apply) type class with a
"bind" operation `(>>=)` which composes computations in sequence, using
the return value of one computation to determine the next computation.

The `>>=` operator can also be expressed using `do` notation, as follows:

```purescript
x >>= f = do y <- x
             f y
```

where the function argument of `f` is given the name `y`.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Apply`
laws:

- Associativity: `(x >>= f) >>= g = x >>= (\k -> f k >>= g)`

Associativity tells us that we can regroup operations which use `do`
notation so that we can unambiguously write, for example:

```purescript
do x <- m1
   y <- m2 x
   m3 x y
```
declarations.title: Bind

declarations.comments:
A class for types whose values can safely be discarded
in a `do` notation block.

An example is the `Unit` type, since there is only one
possible value which can be returned.
declarations.title: Discard

declarations.comments: Collapse two applications of a monadic type constructor into one.
declarations.title: join

declarations.comments:
Execute a monadic action if a condition holds.

For example:

```purescript
main = ifM ((< 0.5) <$> random)
         (trace "Heads")
         (trace "Tails")
```
declarations.title: ifM

declarations.comments:
`Category`s consist of objects and composable morphisms between them, and
as such are [`Semigroupoids`](#semigroupoid), but unlike `semigroupoids`
must have an identity element.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the
`Semigroupoid` law:

- Identity: `identity <<< p = p <<< identity = p`
declarations.title: Category

declarations.comments:
The `Monad` type class combines the operations of the `Bind` and
`Applicative` type classes. Therefore, `Monad` instances represent type
constructors which support sequential composition, and also lifting of
functions of arbitrary arity.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the
`Applicative` and `Bind` laws:

- Left Identity: `pure x >>= f = f x`
- Right Identity: `x >>= pure = x`
- Applicative Superclass: `apply = ap`
declarations.title: Monad

declarations.comments:
Perform a monadic action when a condition is true, where the conditional
value is also in a monadic context.
declarations.title: whenM

declarations.comments:
Perform a monadic action unless a condition is true, where the conditional
value is also in a monadic context.
declarations.title: unlessM

declarations.comments:
`liftM1` provides a default implementation of `(<$>)` for any
[`Monad`](#monad), without using `(<$>)` as provided by the
[`Functor`](#functor)-[`Monad`](#monad) superclass relationship.

`liftM1` can therefore be used to write [`Functor`](#functor) instances
as follows:

```purescript
instance functorF :: Functor F where
  map = liftM1
```
declarations.title: liftM1

declarations.comments:
`ap` provides a default implementation of `(<*>)` for any
[`Monad`](#monad), without using `(<*>)` as provided by the
[`Apply`](#apply)-[`Monad`](#monad) superclass relationship.

`ap` can therefore be used to write [`Apply`](#apply) instances as
follows:

```purescript
instance applyF :: Apply F where
  apply = ap
```
declarations.title: ap

declarations.comments:
A `Semigroupoid` is similar to a [`Category`](#category) but does not
require an identity element `identity`, just composable morphisms.

`Semigroupoid`s must satisfy the following law:

- Associativity: `p <<< (q <<< r) = (p <<< q) <<< r`

One example of a `Semigroupoid` is the function type constructor `(->)`,
with `(<<<)` defined as function composition.
declarations.title: Semigroupoid

declarations.comments:
An alias for `true`, which can be useful in guard clauses:

```purescript
max x y | x >= y    = x
        | otherwise = y
```
declarations.title: otherwise

declarations.comments:
The `BooleanAlgebra` type class represents types that behave like boolean
values.

Instances should satisfy the following laws in addition to the
`HeytingAlgebra` law:

- Excluded middle:
  - `a || not a = tt`
declarations.title: BooleanAlgebra

children.comments:
The `Bounded` `Int` instance has `top :: Int` equal to 2^31 - 1,
and `bottom :: Int` equal to -2^31, since these are the largest and smallest
integers representable by twos-complement 32-bit integers, respectively.
children.title: boundedInt

children.comments: Characters fall within the Unicode range.
children.title: boundedChar

declarations.comments:
The `Bounded` type class represents totally ordered types that have an
upper and lower boundary.

Instances should satisfy the following law in addition to the `Ord` laws:

- Bounded: `bottom <= a <= top`
declarations.title: Bounded

declarations.comments:
The `CommutativeRing` class is for rings where multiplication is
commutative.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Ring`
laws:

- Commutative multiplication: `a * b = b * a`
declarations.title: CommutativeRing

declarations.comments:
The `DivisionRing` class is for non-zero rings in which every non-zero
element has a multiplicative inverse. Division rings are sometimes also
called *skew fields*.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the `Ring` laws:

- Non-zero ring: `one /= zero`
- Non-zero multiplicative inverse: `recip a * a = a * recip a = one` for
  all non-zero `a`

The result of `recip zero` is left undefined; individual instances may
choose how to handle this case.

If a type has both `DivisionRing` and `CommutativeRing` instances, then
it is a field and should have a `Field` instance.
declarations.title: DivisionRing

declarations.comments:
The `Eq` type class represents types which support decidable equality.

`Eq` instances should satisfy the following laws:

- Reflexivity: `x == x = true`
- Symmetry: `x == y = y == x`
- Transitivity: if `x == y` and `y == z` then `x == z`

**Note:** The `Number` type is not an entirely law abiding member of this
class due to the presence of `NaN`, since `NaN /= NaN`. Additionally,
computing with `Number` can result in a loss of precision, so sometimes
values that should be equivalent are not.
declarations.title: Eq

declarations.comments:
`notEq` tests whether one value is _not equal_ to another. Shorthand for
`not (eq x y)`.
declarations.title: notEq

declarations.comments:
The `EuclideanRing` class is for commutative rings that support division.
The mathematical structure this class is based on is sometimes also called
a *Euclidean domain*.

Instances must satisfy the following laws in addition to the `Ring`
laws:

- Integral domain: `one /= zero`, and if `a` and `b` are both nonzero then
  so is their product `a * b`
- Euclidean function `degree`:
  - Nonnegativity: For all nonzero `a`, `degree a >= 0`
  - Quotient/remainder: For all `a` and `b`, where `b` is nonzero,
    let `q = a / b` and ``r = a `mod` b``; then `a = q*b + r`, and also
    either `r = zero` or `degree r < degree b`
- Submultiplicative euclidean function:
  - For all nonzero `a` and `b`, `degree a <= degree (a * b)`

The behaviour of division by `zero` is unconstrained by these laws,
meaning that individual instances are free to choose how to behave in this
case. Similarly, there are no restrictions on what the result of
`degree zero` is; it doesn't make sense to ask for `degree zero` in the
same way that it doesn't make sense to divide by `zero`, so again,
individual instances may choose how to handle this case.

For any `EuclideanRing` which is also a `Field`, one valid choice
for `degree` is simply `const 1`. In fact, unless there's a specific
reason not to, `Field` types should normally use this definition of
`degree`.

The `EuclideanRing Int` instance is one of the most commonly used
`EuclideanRing` instances and deserves a little more discussion. In
particular, there are a few different sensible law-abiding implementations
to choose from, with slightly different behaviour in the presence of
negative dividends or divisors. The most common definitions are "truncating"
division, where the result of `a / b` is rounded towards 0, and "Knuthian"
or "flooring" division, where the result of `a / b` is rounded towards
negative infinity. A slightly less common, but arguably more useful, option
is "Euclidean" division, which is defined so as to ensure that ``a `mod` b``
is always nonnegative. With Euclidean division, `a / b` rounds towards
negative infinity if the divisor is positive, and towards positive infinity
if the divisor is negative. Note that all three definitions are identical if
we restrict our attention to nonnegative dividends and divisors.

In versions 1.x, 2.x, and 3.x of the Prelude, the `EuclideanRing Int`
instance used truncating division. As of 4.x, the `EuclideanRing Int`
instance uses Euclidean division. Additional functions `quot` and `rem` are
supplied if truncating division is desired.
declarations.title: EuclideanRing

declarations.comments: The *least common multiple* of two values.
declarations.title: lcm

declarations.comments: The *greatest common divisor* of two values.
declarations.title: gcd

declarations.comments:
The `Field` class is for types that are (commutative) fields.

Mathematically, a field is a ring which is commutative and in which every
nonzero element has a multiplicative inverse; these conditions correspond
to the `CommutativeRing` and `DivisionRing` classes in PureScript
respectively. However, the `Field` class has `EuclideanRing` and
`DivisionRing` as superclasses, which seems like a stronger requirement
(since `CommutativeRing` is a superclass of `EuclideanRing`). In fact, it
is not stronger, since any type which has law-abiding `CommutativeRing`
and `DivisionRing` instances permits exactly one law-abiding
`EuclideanRing` instance. We use a `EuclideanRing` superclass here in
order to ensure that a `Field` constraint on a function permits you to use
`div` on that type, since `div` is a member of `EuclideanRing`.

This class has no laws or members of its own; it exists as a convenience,
so a single constraint can be used when field-like behaviour is expected.

This module also defines a single `Field` instance for any type which has
both `EuclideanRing` and `DivisionRing` instances. Any other instance
would overlap with this instance, so no other `Field` instances should be
defined in libraries. Instead, simply define `EuclideanRing` and
`DivisionRing` instances, and this will permit your type to be used with a
`Field` constraint.
declarations.title: Field

declarations.comments:
Flips the order of the arguments to a function of two arguments.

```purescript
flip const 1 2 = const 2 1 = 2
```
declarations.title: flip

declarations.comments:
Returns its first argument and ignores its second.

```purescript
const 1 "hello" = 1
```
declarations.title: const

declarations.comments:
Applies a function to an argument: the reverse of `(#)`.

```purescript
length $ groupBy productCategory $ filter isInStock $ products
```

is equivalent to:

```purescript
length (groupBy productCategory (filter isInStock products))
```

Or another alternative equivalent, applying chain of composed functions to
a value:

```purescript
length <<< groupBy productCategory <<< filter isInStock $ products
```

Applies an argument to a function: the reverse of `($)`.

```purescript
products # filter isInStock # groupBy productCategory # length
```

is equivalent to:

```purescript
length (groupBy productCategory (filter isInStock products))
```

Or another alternative equivalent, applying a value to a chain of composed
functions:

```purescript
products # filter isInStock >>> groupBy productCategory >>> length
```

A `Functor` is a type constructor which supports a mapping operation
`map`.

`map` can be used to turn functions `a -> b` into functions
`f a -> f b` whose argument and return types use the type constructor `f`
to represent some computational context.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Identity: `map identity = identity`
- Composition: `map (f <<< g) = map f <<< map g`
declarations.title: Functor

declarations.comments:
The `void` function is used to ignore the type wrapped by a
[`Functor`](#functor), replacing it with `Unit` and keeping only the type
information provided by the type constructor itself.

`void` is often useful when using `do` notation to change the return type
of a monadic computation:

```purescript
main = forE 1 10 \n -> void do
  print n
  print (n * n)
```
declarations.title: void

declarations.comments:
Apply a value in a computational context to a value in no context.

Generalizes `flip`.

```purescript
longEnough :: String -> Bool
hasSymbol :: String -> Bool
hasDigit :: String -> Bool
password :: String

validate :: String -> Array Bool
validate = flap [longEnough, hasSymbol, hasDigit]
```

```purescript
flap (-) 3 4 == 1
threeve <$> Just 1 <@> 'a' <*> Just true == Just (threeve 1 'a' true)
```
declarations.title: flap

declarations.comments:
The `HeytingAlgebra` type class represents types that are bounded lattices with
an implication operator such that the following laws hold:

- Associativity:
  - `a || (b || c) = (a || b) || c`
  - `a && (b && c) = (a && b) && c`
- Commutativity:
  - `a || b = b || a`
  - `a && b = b && a`
- Absorption:
  - `a || (a && b) = a`
  - `a && (a || b) = a`
- Idempotent:
  - `a || a = a`
  - `a && a = a`
- Identity:
  - `a || ff = a`
  - `a && tt = a`
- Implication:
  - ``a `implies` a = tt``
  - ``a && (a `implies` b) = a && b``
  - ``b && (a `implies` b) = b``
  - ``a `implies` (b && c) = (a `implies` b) && (a `implies` c)``
- Complemented:
  - ``not a = a `implies` ff``
declarations.title: HeytingAlgebra

declarations.comments:
A `Monoid` is a `Semigroup` with a value `mempty`, which is both a
left and right unit for the associative operation `<>`:

```
forall x. mempty <> x = x <> mempty = x
```

`Monoid`s are commonly used as the result of fold operations, where
`<>` is used to combine individual results, and `mempty` gives the result
of folding an empty collection of elements.
declarations.title: Monoid

declarations.comments:
The `Ord` type class represents types which support comparisons with a
_total order_.

`Ord` instances should satisfy the laws of total orderings:

- Reflexivity: `a <= a`
- Antisymmetry: if `a <= b` and `b <= a` then `a = b`
- Transitivity: if `a <= b` and `b <= c` then `a <= c`
declarations.title: Ord

declarations.comments:
Take the minimum of two values. If they are considered equal, the first
argument is chosen.
declarations.title: min

declarations.comments:
Take the maximum of two values. If they are considered equal, the first
argument is chosen.
declarations.title: max

declarations.comments: Compares two values by mapping them to a type with an `Ord` instance.
declarations.title: comparing

declarations.comments:
Clamp a value between a minimum and a maximum. For example:

``` purescript
let f = clamp 0 10
f (-5) == 0
f 5    == 5
f 15   == 10
```
declarations.title: clamp

declarations.comments:
Test whether a value is between a minimum and a maximum (inclusive).
For example:

``` purescript
let f = between 0 10
f 0    == true
f (-5) == false
f 5    == true
f 10   == true
f 15   == false
```
declarations.title: between

declarations.comments:
The `Ordering` data type represents the three possible outcomes of
comparing two values:

`LT` - The first value is _less than_ the second.
`GT` - The first value is _greater than_ the second.
`EQ` - The first value is _equal to_ the second.
declarations.title: Ordering

declarations.comments:
The `Ring` class is for types that support addition, multiplication,
and subtraction operations.

Instances must satisfy the following law in addition to the `Semiring`
laws:

- Additive inverse: `a - a = (zero - a) + a = zero`
declarations.title: Ring

declarations.comments: `negate x` can be used as a shorthand for `zero - x`.
declarations.title: negate

declarations.comments:
The `Semigroup` type class identifies an associative operation on a type.

Instances are required to satisfy the following law:

- Associativity: `(x <> y) <> z = x <> (y <> z)`

One example of a `Semigroup` is `String`, with `(<>)` defined as string
concatenation.
declarations.title: Semigroup

declarations.comments:
The `Semiring` class is for types that support an addition and
multiplication operation.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:

- Commutative monoid under addition:
  - Associativity: `(a + b) + c = a + (b + c)`
  - Identity: `zero + a = a + zero = a`
  - Commutative: `a + b = b + a`
- Monoid under multiplication:
  - Associativity: `(a * b) * c = a * (b * c)`
  - Identity: `one * a = a * one = a`
- Multiplication distributes over addition:
  - Left distributivity: `a * (b + c) = (a * b) + (a * c)`
  - Right distributivity: `(a + b) * c = (a * c) + (b * c)`
- Annihilation: `zero * a = a * zero = zero`

**Note:** The `Number` and `Int` types are not fully law abiding
members of this class hierarchy due to the potential for arithmetic
overflows, and in the case of `Number`, the presence of `NaN` and
`Infinity` values. The behaviour is unspecified in these cases.
declarations.title: Semiring

declarations.comments:
The `Show` type class represents those types which can be converted into
a human-readable `String` representation.

While not required, it is recommended that for any expression `x`, the
string `show x` be executable PureScript code which evaluates to the same
value as the expression `x`.
declarations.title: Show

declarations.comments:
The `Unit` type has a single inhabitant, called `unit`. It represents
values with no computational content.

`Unit` is often used, wrapped in a monadic type constructor, as the
return type of a computation where only
the _effects_ are important.
declarations.title: Unit

declarations.comments: `unit` is the sole inhabitant of the `Unit` type.
declarations.title: unit

declarations.comments:
An uninhabited data type.

`Void` is useful to eliminate the possibility of a value being created.
For example, a value of type `Either Void Boolean` can never have
a Left value created in PureScript.
declarations.title: Void

modules.name: Record.Unsafe
modules.comments:
The functions in this module are highly unsafe as they treat records like
stringly-keyed maps and can coerce the row of labels that a record has.

These function are intended for situations where there is some other way of
proving things about the structure of the record - for example, when using
`RowToList`. **They should never be used for general record manipulation.**

declarations.comments: Checks if a record has a key, using a string for the key.
declarations.title: unsafeHas

declarations.comments:
Unsafely gets a value from a record, using a string for the key.

If the key does not exist this will cause a runtime error elsewhere.
declarations.title: unsafeGet

declarations.comments:
Unsafely sets a value on a record, using a string for the key.

The output record's row is unspecified so can be coerced to any row. If the
output type is incorrect it will cause a runtime error elsewhere.
declarations.title: unsafeSet

declarations.comments:
Unsafely removes a value on a record, using a string for the key.

The output record's row is unspecified so can be coerced to any row. If the
output type is incorrect it will cause a runtime error elsewhere.
declarations.title: unsafeDelete

declarations.comments: A proxy to carry information about a rowlist.
declarations.title: RLProxy
